awd_titl_txt: Curriculum and Assessment Design to Study the Development of Motivation and Computational Thinking for Middle School Students across Three Learning Contexts
awd_abstract_narration:
Computing has become an integral part of practice within modern fields of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). As a result, the STEM+Computing Partnerships (STEM+C) program seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the integration of computing and computational thinking in STEM teaching and learning and broadening participation of students in computing and computing-intensive fields. This project builds upon a successful prior afterschool program for teaching computational thinking (TECHFIT), expanding it to include two additional new learning contexts: an elective class; as embedded modules within discipline-based middle school courses; together with the existing afterschool program. A total of 165 teachers (including 144 new teachers) and 2850 middle school students (grades 6-8) at schools with large underserved and/or minority populations will be involved in the project.  The project has two core objectives: 1) to develop and validate a computational thinking assessment tool; and, 2) to examine the development of computational thinking and motivation in middle school students across the three contexts (afterschool, in-school class, embedded modules). The learning activity for students involves engaging in a game-based activity for physical fitness by using the programming language Scratch, flowchart programming, and via a microcontroller with electronic parts. 

The research employs a pretest-posttest multi-site, randomized controlled trial design to determine the impact of three learning contexts (after-school program, in-school course, and instructional modules) on students' pre-/post computational thinking skills, motivation, self-efficacy for computing, and interest in and aspiration for computing careers. New instruments will be developed and validated to evaluate the extent to which students learn computational thinking skills. The research will examine the relationships among motivational factors and computational thinking in the three learning contexts to determine if context influences teacher delivery and student experiences, and ultimately the development of computational thinking.

por.por_cntn:
Transitioning successful after-school STEM programs to in-school can increase reach by removing barriers that limit participation of underserved students. Given that teachers may experience different demands, expectations and freedoms in the in-school and after-school contexts, and that teachers? perceptions of their work environment are shown to change their classroom behaviors and experiences, program delivery context could influence the overall learning environment and, resultantly, program aims. Even when program fidelity is maintained, this change in learning context could impact student experiences and, ultimately, program efficacy by altering how students and teachers interact. This project?s objectives were to adapt the TECHFIT (DRL- 1312215) afterschool curriculum for use in school and study the ways in which implementation in the two learning contexts (after-school and in school) was connected to the motivational context created by the teacher and the motivational context experienced by the student. Results showed that teachers created similar motivational environments for student learning in both contexts and students' perceptions of the motivational climate did not differ significantly across in-school or afterschool contexts. Together, these findings demonstrate that both teachers and students perceive that the application of adaptive and motivational classroom management strategies is not contingent on an in- or after-school program delivery. 

This project showed teachers how to integrate computational thinking concepts into their classrooms using the TECHIFT curriculum and activities. The training experiences were used to elicit teachers? conceptions about computational thinking and understand how these teachers conceptualized computational thinking. After analysis of teachers? concept maps and in-depth interviews with teachers, we found that there were three general approaches to describing computational thinking: 1) a new way to package and communicate existing skills such as critical thinking; 2) ways to think with technology or approach problem solving that utilizes computing technology; 3) a unique set of thinking practices (e.g., abstraction, decomposition) that cultivate habits of thinking that are distinct from other ways of thinking and knowing. The length of a teacher?s teaching experience was associated with their views. Veteran teachers were well represented in group 1, whereas less experienced teachers were more common in group 2. Teachers? different ways of describing computational thinking influenced their plans and ideas about how to integrate computational thinking into their classroom and the challenges they envisioned. 

The breadth of content and pace of instruction of the summer teacher training has been described as a boot camp experience. Nonetheless, all of the teachers who began the summer training demonstrated by the last day that they had sufficient understanding to successfully teach the hands-on, technology-focused, STEM curriculum to their students. The 2020 pandemic presented unexpected challenges to the project?s instructional team, but the challenges resulted in the creation of additional resources for teachers that further supported their own virtual delivery to their students. Many teachers said that without this program, very few students at their school would have been exposed to technology, engineering, and computing, so although it was challenging work for them, it was also important. The external evaluator's feedback to the team showed that support from the schools themselves directly impacted the teachers' abilities to successfully implement the program.

Teachers are ready to learn more about computational thinking and welcome more computational thinking resources/training. Researchers, school districts, professional education associations should provide teachers with the needed resources/activities based on their existing views about computational thinking and maintain adequate support throughout implementation to yield successful outcomes.
